title: Regeneration as a fundamental characteristic of living systems

previewContent.subtitle: A conversation between Fritjof Capra and Daniel Wahl (Transcript Part II)

paragraphs.name: previewTitle
paragraphs.text: Regeneration as a fundamental characteristic of living systems

paragraphs.name: previewSubtitle
paragraphs.text: A conversation between Fritjof Capra…

creator.name: Daniel Christian Wahl
creator.bio: Catalysing transformative innovation, cultural co-creation, whole systems design, and bioregional regeneration. Author of Designing Regenerative Cultures

paragraphs.name: b116
paragraphs.text: Regeneration is fundamental to living systems

paragraphs.name: d353
paragraphs.text: A conversation between Fritjof Capra and Daniel Wahl (Transcript Part II — still unedited)

paragraphs.name: b85a
paragraphs.text: Daniel:

paragraphs.name: 868c
paragraphs.text: Okay. Wonderful. We’re back recording. Thanks so much for the conversation we just had, part one, and now we’re taking a little bit of a deep dive into some of the things that I learned from you and also, would love to have your reflections on in terms of my own learning. One, I came a couple of years ago, when I was writing my book, Designing Regenerative Cultures, I came across the work of a biologist and systems theorist called John Stewart. He described evolution in a way that I’d not heard it described before, but it really made a lot of sense to me. He said that the general process of evolution is a process of diversification and then subsequent integration of that diversity at higher levels of complexity. He said that more often than not in the long arc of evolution, that reintegration of diversity at higher levels of complexity, happens through collaborative processes, whether this is two long nucleated cells and one engulfing the other and forming nucleated cells, the endless symbiosis theory and what that made possible in terms of multicellular organism and most of higher life forms being based on nucleated cells.

paragraphs.name: 60e8
paragraphs.text: Daniel:

paragraphs.name: 189d
paragraphs.text: Then how that, from multicellular organism to social organisms, every time you get, or the complexity of ecosystems, the process by which life creates conditions conducive to life seems to be so much more symbiotic and symphonic all together, optimizing the whole system than it is about competing individuals one against the other. I mean, both hands. Do you agree that we might have, in evolutionary theory and also in education around biology and evolution, have somewhat over focused on competition as a driving force in evolution and have undervalued the ocean of symbiosis and collaboration that actually underlies that when you zoom out and you take a systems view of life [inaudible 00:02:09]?

paragraphs.name: 58bb
paragraphs.text: Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: 6e89
paragraphs.text: Absolutely, absolutely. But first let me say that I really like Stewart’s way of describing evolution and the emphasis on cooperation makes total sense because it is actually impolite in the diversification. If you understand life as a network, then biodiversity means higher complexity of the network, more connections. Since this living network is a network of processes of metabolic and cognitive processes and ecological processes, every new connection can be seen as a cooperation. Connections are cooperations and greater diversity means more cooperation, or if the cooperation lacks, of course, it means breakdown. Then you have this situation like we have in our political world where we have prejudice in groups fighting each other and distinguishing between us and them, the me and the other. That is the lack of cooperation, but nature, nonhuman nature, that doesn’t work like that. It cooperates, but basically.

paragraphs.name: c67a
paragraphs.text: Fritjof:

One of my great mentors in biology has been Lynn Margulis, the famous microbiologist who really taught me that among many things, that there are three avenues of evolution that classical new Darwinian theory, the modern synthesis, as it’s also called, recognizes only random mutations followed by natural selection. Random mutations are only part of evolution. Bacteria can mutate very fast and multiply very fast, but they have another way of changing the genome. That is by a horizontal gene transfer. They trade genes. They spill out. The bacterium will in day to day, in its day to day life, it will spill out a certain proportion of its genes and other bacteria will absorb it. There’s a constant trading of genes to the extent that some microbiologists think that one should not talk about species of bacteria, because the genome is so fluid and always changing that you can’t define species.

paragraphs.name: bdd8
paragraphs.text: Daniel:

paragraphs.name: 7bb1
paragraphs.text: Just briefly, in a similar way, I find that when we talk about ourselves, homo sapiens, which is a bit … Well, sapiens, sapiens, which is slightly arrogant compared to how we’re currently performing. We are not one species. We are walking ecosystems. The amount of gut flora and skin flora that we have that maintain as a life and healthy. We actually have more non-human cells in our bodies and on our bodies than we have human cells.

paragraphs.name: 24d5
paragraphs.text: Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: 810e
paragraphs.text: Absolutely, absolutely. Yes. The second avenue evolution is the gene trading and the third avenue of evolution is something that Lynn Margulis popularized and built a theory around. That’s symbiosis. There are two organisms living in close proximity to the extent that they ended up completely, depending on one another and forming a new organism. For example, the chloroplasts in plant cells that contain the chlorophyll and are essential for the synthesis were originally individual bacteria that invaded the cell and then became comfortable there and collaborated cooperated with the plant cell. You have these three avenues of evolution, genetic random mutation, which it’s not that random either, but let’s not get into that. It becomes too complicated. Random, well, let me just say that an organism can control the amount of randomness. The random mutation is based on a copying arrow of the DNA and the arrow.
Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: 74e3
paragraphs.text: The amount of arrow can be controlled by the organism, but that’s a whole other story. Anyway, you have random mutation, gene trading and sym biogenesis as Margulis calls it. Now what happens then is you have a new genome and that new genome has to be integrated into it’s environment. Into its cellular environment, into its tissue environment and into the larger environment. Natural selection will see to it that only the successful integration can survive.
Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: ce3f
paragraphs.text: Now, this integration of a new genome in its environment is a highly ordered and very complex process. I remember spending hours with Lynne one evening at the Cortona School that Pier Luigi Luisi organized late at night, where she explained to me how genomes are integrated in the environment. My head began to swim. It’s very, very complex. Evolution has random elements, but overall it is an audit process. It is a complex process. It is a cooperative process. As we’ve come to understand, it is a cognitive process because according to the so-called Santiago theory of cognition about which I’ve written a lot, the very essential dynamics of self organization is cognitive. That’s a very different view of evolution from the sort of lottery point view of new Darwinist.

paragraphs.name: ff01
paragraphs.text: Daniel:

paragraphs.name: 2ad2
paragraphs.text: You just gave me the key for the next question, because I remember you, and I’m going to paraphrase because I don’t know the exact quote, but I remember you saying something, I think it was even in the turning point, which was that, “If you follow the converging crises that we see around the planet at the moment, the ecological crisis, now you could say the ecological and the climate crisis, the social crisis and social breakdown and the ever faster cycles of economic crisis, if you follow all these rivers upstream, you come to one single source, which is a crisis of perception or a crisis of consciousness.” To some extent, the Santiago theory of cognition is one of the first time theories. That overcomes part of that crisis of consciousness that dualism between mind and matter self and world nature culture. The way that we tend to distinguish things in a Cartesian framework rather than pay attention to the dimension of mind in what we’re observing.

paragraphs.name: 033e
paragraphs.text: Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: 3c98
paragraphs.text: Yeah. I did talk about the crisis of perception I think in the turning point, in the early 1980s. I may have got that phrase from Hazel Henderson, the radical economist, who is an old friend of mine. What we are talking about here is a very profound change of worldview that has been happening over the last half century and longer, the change of paradigms, essentially from seeing the world as a machine, to understanding it as a network. A network, of course, is a pattern of relationships and therefore, in order to understand networks, we need to understand patterns and relationships. That’s what systems thinking is all about. That’s why I call the new paradigm is systemic or systems view of the world. This has a profound effect on all our activities and endeavors, professionally and personally, because what we’re dealing with in our personal and professional lives is usually living systems.

paragraphs.name: 9b6a
paragraphs.text: Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: dd7a
paragraphs.text: Whether we talk about the economy or education or health care or management, all that has to do with life. The profound change from seeing life is a clockwork, as a machine to understanding it as a network of processes and as a cognitive network. This is now what the Santiago theory, developed by Humberto Marturano and Francisco Varela at the university of Santiago in Chile. What this theory says is that the dynamics of organizational of self organization, of living organisms or any living systems is essentially a cognitive process. This is a great expansion of the view of cognition. Cognition is the self organizing activity of living systems. When an organism perceives something, that stimulus, that disturbance as Marturano calls it, will enter the organism and the organism will respond to it with certain structural changes, according to its nature. The environment triggers the response, triggers the structural changes, but doesn’t determine them. The organism actually selects what to notice and what not to notice.

paragraphs.name: 8cc5
paragraphs.text: Daniel:

paragraphs.name: a12e
paragraphs.text: If I understand them correctly. We talked earlier about the kind of parallels of the wisdom traditions to science. What Maturana & Varela call the first distinction brings forth the actual the organism observed, in the structural coupling between organism and environment, the environment actually becomes the environment, the organism becomes organisms. It’s this first distinction of the boundary between organism and environment that is the beginning of that process of autopoiesis.

paragraphs.name: 48b4
paragraphs.text: Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: 0d07
paragraphs.text: That’s right. Yes.

paragraphs.name: a0f6
paragraphs.text: Daniel:

paragraphs.name: 4ffb
paragraphs.text: Sorry, I didn’t want to interrupt you.
Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: ee53
paragraphs.text: No, no, no, no, no. That’s all right. When we adopt this view of seeing life around us as cognitive systems, and therefore as intelligent, this will profoundly influence the way we deal with our environment. If the environment really were a machine, then the best way to deal with it would be to control it. That’s what you do when you drive your car, you need to control it. Otherwise, you get into trouble. The way one deals with the machine is to control it. If the environment is a living system, a living being, an intelligent being, then the best way to deal with it is not via domination and control, but via dialogue and cooperation and partnership.

paragraphs.name: 61e4
paragraphs.text: Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: e3a4
paragraphs.text: There’s so much we can learn from nature. Rather than controlling nature, or rather than extracting things from nature for our use, we can extract knowledge from nature and can learn from nature because natural systems have solved many of the problems we’re struggling with millions of years ago. There’s this whole movement of equal design and bio mimicry that tries to learn from nature and copy nature to design human structure.

paragraphs.name: 65e9
paragraphs.text: Daniel:

I’m tempted to, in terms of the languages, because we’re talking about the upstream perception change or the consciousness change, the way we use the word nature, and you’ve just done it yourself and Janine does it with bio mimicry. It’s learning from nature. When we say from, we actually put nature back out there again, but of course, what we’re really talking about is that we, as human beings, are part of that process and we learn as nature from the wider community of life.
Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: 6a2b
paragraphs.text: Yeah, yeah. That’s right. But of course, when you interact with somebody, there are connections, but there are also differences. I learned from you and you learned from me and we both learned from nature.

paragraphs.name: 9a5f
paragraphs.text: Daniel:

paragraphs.name: 3ef2
paragraphs.text: Yeah. As the wider context. For me, so much about, I mean, to some extent, the Santiago theory also speaks to what is life. In the work that I do with bringing in this concept of regeneration as life, as a regenerative community, to understand how life, we were talking about it earlier. These patterns of complex education also then in local pockets, need breakdown of ossified structures that no longer serve in order to unleash the possibility for new connections. In your book, The Systems View of Life, you have two sub chapters. One of them ask the question, what is life? Then you also asked the question, what is death? I think that the second part, we often culturally are to booing death as something negative, but in many ways, Goethe more than 200 years ago said that death is life’s ingenious way to create plenty of life. I would love for you to speak to that dynamic relationship between life and death and how that might inform us to participate in that longer cycle more wisely.

paragraphs.name: d5c0
paragraphs.text: Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: 0bb3
paragraphs.text: No. Yeah. I didn’t know this saying of Goethe. That’s very beautiful. Well, of course the central question that I’ve been exploring for the last 30 years is the question, what is life? The age old question, what is life? When you go around too biology departments and ask the professors there, what’s your definition of life, then they tend to focus on the structures of living systems. They might say, “Well, the essential difference between a rock and the plant is the fact that a plant is made of cells. All living systems are either individual cells or made of cells. A rock is not made of cells. Within the cells, there are very large molecules, macromolecules like proteins, lipids, DNA, RNA with a carbon backbone.”

paragraphs.name: 13f3
paragraphs.text: Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: 46fb
paragraphs.text: They don’t exist in non-living systems. Some biologists might even say, “Well, life is a … a living organism is a chemical system made of DNA. All you have to do is really look for DNA. If you see DNA it’s alive, if you don’t see DNA, it’s not alive.” Well, this sounds very simple, but it is a flawed because dead organisms also contain DNA. When an organism dies, the DNA doesn’t disappear, it’s just a molecule and it stays there. The difference between the living and the dead organism or living and the nonliving organism is the process of flight is what poets and philosophers for ages have called the breath of life. In modern scientific language, the breath of life is called metabolism. This is something I learned also from Lynn Margulis. She defines metabolism as a constant flow of energy and matter through a network of processes of chemical reactions in a cell, for example, which allows the organism continually to continually regenerate itself, repair itself and perpetuate itself.

paragraphs.name: 5b80
paragraphs.text: Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: f598
paragraphs.text: In this definition of metabolism, there are two aspects, the flow aspect and the network aspect. My synthesis of this whole systems view of life is essentially a synthesis between the flow aspect and the network aspect. The flow aspect was researched and developed by Ilya Prigogine in his concept of dissipative structures of systems being continuously far from equilibrium, subject to constant flows of energy and matter. Then the network aspect was developed by Marturana and Varela, who discovered that the key characteristic of these living networks is that there are cells generating self producing, self making. They’re calling the Greek term, which literally means self making that’s autopoiesis. These autopoietic networks continually regenerate themselves, replace their structures, transform their structures and regenerate themselves. You must like that very much because you have written this book about regenerative cultures and regeneration, is a term that has become very popular lately thanks partly to your work. We can say that if you really understand the systemic nature of life, in terms of that a living system is a regenerative system. That’s the very definition of life.

paragraphs.name: 89bc
paragraphs.text: Daniel:

paragraphs.name: 9a0c
paragraphs.text: Yeah. Life as a planetary process is a regenerative community. When you were saying Prigogine, I was reminded suddenly that when I first had a conversation with Jim Lovelock at Schumacher College about that first moment when he kind of got struck with the first vision of Gaia as a planetary process. He was actually working on helping to design new instruments for detecting life on Mars. He was at the jet propulsion laboratories at the time and in the office next to him, data, new data came in from radio spectrometry or something of the atmospheric compositions of all the other planets.

paragraphs.name: af1d
paragraphs.text: Daniel:

paragraphs.name: 47ee
paragraphs.text: In his tea break, he just looked at his colleagues dataset and he noticed something that really struck him, which was that on all the other planets in our solar system, there is a chemical equilibrium. Meaning that all the reactions that can happen have already happened and the gases and compositions that have balanced each other out. Then if you look at Gaia, there’s a stark disequilibrium that makes life possible. At that moment, he basically almost got himself out of a job by basically saying, “We don’t need to design more instruments. We don’t need to send anybody up. I can tell you that there isn’t any life there because the process of life is what creates the disequilibrium.”
Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: 5fb3
paragraphs.text: Yeah. Prigogine would say because the Earth is a dissipative structure and Venus and Mars are not dissipative structures. Now, Daniel, do you know was Lovelock aware of Prigogines’ work at that time.
Daniel:

paragraphs.name: fee0
paragraphs.text: I actually don’t know. But in terms of the historics, do you know when Prigogine did his work because this insight is in the 1960s.
Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: be38
paragraphs.text: Yes. around about at the same time.

paragraphs.name: a209
paragraphs.text: Daniel:

paragraphs.name: aef3
paragraphs.text: Yeah. I think they must have … as happens. People have the same insights because we’re all connected.

paragraphs.name: edc2
paragraphs.text: Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: 16cb
paragraphs.text: Maturana and Bateson. Bateson with his concept of mind as a systems phenomenon and Maturana with his idea of cognition as the dynamics of self organization. Let’s go on to you were asking me about also, and this spot in our textbook is actually about what Luisi wrote. What he says is that life is a certain pattern. It’s a pattern of self organization, of self generation, of regeneration. Death is the breaking of that pattern. That pattern may break all of a sudden when somebody has a car accident and dies on the spot or a stroke or a heart attack, or what is much more common, the pattern may break slowly. That’s the process of aging. Certain collections no longer work, or I know from my experience as I’m getting older, my hearing is not what it used to be. My attention span is not what it used to be. Of course, we wear glasses. I take naps in the afternoon. I don’t have to. I can survive without a nap in the afternoon, but I really like it.

paragraphs.name: bca7
paragraphs.text: Daniel:

paragraphs.name: 22b1
paragraphs.text: I highly recommend it. It’s my grandmother’s recipe for success. She turned 103.

paragraphs.name: 3e62
paragraphs.text: Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: f7ac
paragraphs.text: Yeah. The slow breaking of this pattern of connections is what aging is and eventually resulting in death.

paragraphs.name: 53bb
paragraphs.text: Daniel:

paragraphs.name: b463
paragraphs.text: At the end of your book, because before we go there, I wanted to pick up on that dimension of breakdown or periodic disturbance in the … If we zoom out from the kind of individual focus on life, and we really look at life as a systemic phenomenon across ecosystems that maintain planetary health and the conditions conducive to life for life on the planet. I sense that there’s a lot of discussion at the moment about, are we in collapse? Is it already too late? Life itself teaches that at the edge of chaos, the system is at its most creative, because the rigidity of the structures that have created the imbalance also begin to break down and I feel like that’s exactly what’s happening right now around the globe.

paragraphs.name: c0bd
paragraphs.text: Daniel:

We see system’s crumbling and it’s alarming and it’s disconcerting and withered, we also see evil monsters of the past rear their ugly heads as people, demagogues, try to use that opportunity of multiple breakdowns for their own benefits. Ultimately, the positive take on that would be that these breakdowns are actually part of the systemic transformation that is now really on the way and that that actually is part of life’s pattern. Do you resonate with that reading?

paragraphs.name: d19a
paragraphs.text: Fritjof:

Absolutely, because something we haven’t talked about yet is the process of emergence, which is a key characteristic of life in the systems view of life. This is something that has been developed by Ilia Prigogine. To me, understanding the process of emergence is probably the biggest achievement of complexity theory. What we have understood is that even though all living organisms maintain themselves in a state of balance in the state of homeostasis every now and then they will encounter a point of imbalance. At that point of imbalance, and Prigogine described this dynamic. There is a disturbance either from the environment or from the inner workings of the organism and that disturbance gets sent around feedback loops and goes around and around and gets amplified.

paragraphs.name: d48b
paragraphs.text: Fritjof:

As you know, there are two kinds of feedback. Self-balancing feedback and self amplifying feedback. It gets amplified and amplified until the system as a whole reaches a state of crisis, a state of imbalance, technically known as bifurcation point. It can then go in different directions. It will either breakdown or more frequently will break through to a new state of order. This is what we’re experiencing now in the world at large. There is imbalance. There is crisis. There is emergency, and hopefully we will be able to break through to a new state of higher order.
Daniel:

paragraphs.name: 12f5
paragraphs.text: Yeah. No, that’s exactly where I feel we’re at and the jury is still out, whether we’re going to make it.

paragraphs.name: 45b0
paragraphs.text: Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: 02ed
paragraphs.text: Daniel, I want to come back to life and death and that beautiful quotation from Goethe that you mentioned. That is totally born out by science because when you think of living systems as constantly renewing themselves, and when you think of this constant regeneration, as the very essence of life and apply this to a human organism, then we know that we constantly renew and recycle ourselves very rapidly in fact. The stomach lining, for instance, changes completely within 24 hours or something like this. Other tissues have a rapid turnover of cells. This constant self-renewal is the very essence of life. Well, if you look at it from the point of view of the cell, it’s a cycle of life and death. What is life and death at one level is the very essence of life at the higher level. That’s a very deep insight. I think this is what Goethe, who had many deep insights meant in this.
Daniel:

paragraphs.name: cbdb
paragraphs.text: This quotation comes from Goethes’ Aphorisms on Nature, which is something that he wrote relatively late in life, where you really, in an essence, picked up some of his learnings. It was actually [inaudible 00:32:17] Huxley’s father or grandfather when he got the opportunity to write the forward for the first edition of nature. He got two pages and he quoted Goethe for almost half or more than half of his two pages saying something along the lines of long after the intellectual pursuits of the people that were published in this journal will be forgotten. The vision of the poet will remain. Then he basically copies a section of Goethes’ Aphorisms on Nature. I’ll send them to you. They’re pure genius.

paragraphs.name: 29cb
paragraphs.text: Fritjof:

paragraphs.name: 6a46
paragraphs.text: Oh, great. Thank you.

paragraphs.name: cb7f
paragraphs.text: Daniel:

paragraphs.name: b7c8
paragraphs.text: I think what I’m going to do is I’m actually going to stop the recording again here, and then we’ll do a third one if you still feel up for it, because it’s been quite a long section.

paragraphs.name: 763e
paragraphs.text: See also this summary with a link to the recording:

paragraphs.name: bbe5
paragraphs.text:
“Living systems are regenerative systems” (Part 2 of 3)

paragraphs.name: 5b79
paragraphs.text: If you like the post, please clap AND remember that you can clap up to 50 times if you like it a lot ;-)!

paragraphs.name: d179
paragraphs.text: Daniel Christian Wahl — Catalyzing transformative innovation in the face of converging crises, advising on regenerative whole systems design, regenerative leadership, and education for regenerative development and bioregional regeneration.

paragraphs.name: 1c98
paragraphs.text: Author of the internationally acclaimed book Designing Regenerative Cultures

paragraphs.name: 01d3

paragraphs.name: ba3e
paragraphs.text:
Daniel Christian Wahl is creating content to support regenerative cultures & regional regeneration…
